prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in physics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in physics would. At a certain amusement park, there is a bulk discount for tickets. If you buy up to 60 tickets in one order, the price for each ticket is $\$70$. However if you buy more than 60 tickets in a single order, the price of every ticket is reduced by $\$1$ for each additional ticket bought. If $t$ is the number of tickets bought in bulk at one time, what is the largest $t$ which will bring the amusement park a profit greater than $\$4200$?
gpt_response:
To solve this problem, we need to first establish the profit function for the amusement park. Let $P(t)$ be the profit function, where $t$ is the number of tickets bought in bulk at one time.

The cost of each ticket is \$70 if the number of tickets bought is up to 60. Therefore, the cost function for the park is:
\[ C(t) = 
\begin{cases} 
70t & \text{for } t\leq 60 \\
70\cdot 60 + (t-60)(70-(t-60)) & \text{for } t>60
\end{cases}
\]

The revenue function can be represented as:
\[ R(t) = 70\cdot t \]

The profit function is given by:
\[ P(t) = R(t) - C(t) \]

Substitute the values of $R(t)$ and $C(t)$ into the profit function:
\[ P(t) = 70t - 
\begin{cases} 
70t & \text{for } t\leq 60 \\
70\cdot 60 + (t-60)(70-(t-60)) & \text{for } t>60
\end{cases}
\]

Simplifying the profit function:
\[ P(t) = 
\begin{cases} 
70t-70t & \text{for } t\leq 60 \\
70t - (70\cdot 60 + (t-60)(70-(t-60))) & \text{for } t>60
\end{cases}
\]

Now, we need to find the largest $t$ which will bring the amusement park a profit greater than \$4200. This translates to finding the maximum value of $t$ such that $P(t) > 4200$.

Solving the inequality $P(t) > 4200$ will give us the largest $t$ which will bring the park a profit greater than \$4200. This can be achieved by analyzing the profit function graphically, by finding the critical points of the profit function, or by using calculus methods to find the maximum value of $t$ that satisfies the inequality.
